dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So Fintiv, which used to be GreenTech Innovations, is now suing Google over a patent they acquired from a German company back in 2017.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Fintiv, which used to be GreenTech Innovations, is now suing Google over a patent they acquired from a German company back in twenty seventeen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Fintiv used to be known by a different name, Mozido, a once-hot mobile payments startup at the center of a large alleged investment fraud and criminal prosecution. In February, two months after Fintiv sued Apple, federal prosecutors in Maine indicted Michael Liberty, accusing the founder of Mozido of orchestrating an investment fraud in connection with his fundraising activity around Mozido, the company he once claimed would revolutionize global payments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's wild that the former CEO, John Smith, uh, pleaded guilty to all those financial misrepresentations and tax evasion charges.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's wild that the former C E O, John Smith, uh, pleaded guilty to all those financial misrepresentations and tax evasion charges.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Liberty, who has pleaded not guilty to the criminal charges filed against him and has previously denied wrongdoing, is one of Fintivs shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and he's accused of diverting something like $500 million in company funds for personal use, which is just staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and he's accused of diverting something like five hundred dollars million in company funds for personal use, which is just staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The SEC claimed Liberty raised $55 million from individuals who thought they were investing in Mozido and diverted a large portion of those funds for his personal use.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the company itself wasn't charged, right? Like, GreenTech—now Fintiv—wasn't implicated in any of that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the company itself wasn't charged, right? Like, GreenTech-now Fintiv-wasn't implicated in any of that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Again, Mozido itself was not accused of any wrongdoing by the SEC.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And they still have major backers too, like BlackRock and George Soros's funds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And they still have major backers too, like BlackRock and George Soros's funds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other shareholders include funds managed by financial giant Wellington Management and hedge fund legend Julian Robertson.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting though, because even after all that, Fintiv is still pushing forward with their solar panel tech and patent licensing strategy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting though, because even after all that, Fintiv is still pushing forward with their solar panel tech and patent licensing strategy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based in Austin, Texas, Fintiv is a virtually unknown entity in the tech world, describing itself as being in the business of mobile payments and marketing campaigns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Adolfo Salume, their current chief executive, mentioned they're trying to commercialize those patents through licensing, not just lawsuits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Adolfo Salume, their current chief executive, mentioned they're trying to commercialize those patents through licensing, not just lawsuits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adolfo Salume, Fintivs chairman, confirmed to Forbes that Mozido is now doing business as Fintiv and that the company is actively working to enforce its broad patent portfolio.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But they did file that suit against Google because, you know, private negotiations fell through.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they did file that suit against Google because, you know, private negotiations fell through.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our first inclination is to have a private negotiation like we did with Apple, and a lawsuit is only a product of the refusal to have a private negotiation, Salume said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's worth noting that some of the board members, like Martha Jones and even Smith's brother David, are still involved with Fintiv.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's worth noting that some of the board members, like Martha Jones and even Smith's brother David, are still involved with Fintiv.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mike Love, who played a big management role at Mozido for years and worked closely with Liberty, is a director of Fintiv. So is Michael Libertys cousin, Stan Liberty.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kind of surprising, considering how closely tied John Smith was to the earlier scandals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kind of surprising, considering how closely tied John Smith was to the earlier scandals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And remember, GreenTech was valued at around $8 billion when they acquired SolarCorp, which was bringing in most of their revenue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And remember, GreenTech was valued at around eight dollars billion when they acquired SolarCorp, which was bringing in most of their revenue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mozido raised $300 million from big investors to build a mobile payments company and was valued at about $5.6 billion when it purchased PayEase, a Chinese payment processor that generated the vast majority of Mozidos revenue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then they sold SolarCorp last year to generate profit—pretty strategic move, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then they sold SolarCorp last year to generate profit-pretty strategic move, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mozido sold its most meaningful unit, PayEase, last year to pay back a large debt obligation that was partly used to repay employees for unpaid work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But it's messy, because some of the funds Smith raised from individual investors allegedly went to settle his own past legal troubles, not into the company.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's messy, because some of the funds Smith raised from individual investors allegedly went to settle his own past legal troubles, not into the company.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He is even accused of using some of the money he raised for Mozido to pay a discouragement penalty issued by a federal judge against Liberty related to a previous Liberty investment scheme that resulted in an SEC enforcement action years ago.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, prosecutors claimed a lot of that half-billion from individuals funded charitable stuff or even personal settlements.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, prosecutors claimed a lot of that half-billion from individuals funded charitable stuff or even personal settlements.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition, Liberty raised some $55 million from individual investors for Mozido, most of which was transferred using shell companies to fund other Liberty companies, payments to his ex-wife and interior decorating, federal prosecutors claim.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, Fintiv seems determined to distance itself and focus on their tech and IP now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, Fintiv seems determined to distance itself and focus on their tech and I P now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Salume made it clear—lawsuits are a last resort; they'd rather license.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Salume made it clear-lawsuits are a last resort; they'd rather license.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are other companies using our technology without a license so part of the task of our board is to protect the value of the investors in the company and we do have a strategy, not for lawsuits but for licenses a last resort is a lawsuit.

artist_script:
HostA: So Fintiv, which used to be GreenTech Innovations, is now suing Google over a patent they acquired from a German company back in 2017.
HostB: Yeah, and it’s wild that the former CEO, John Smith, uh, pleaded guilty to all those financial misrepresentations and tax evasion charges.
HostA: Right, and he’s accused of diverting something like $500 million in company funds for personal use, which is just staggering.
HostB: But the company itself wasn’t charged, right? Like, GreenTech—now Fintiv—wasn’t implicated in any of that.
HostA: Exactly. And they still have major backers too, like BlackRock and George Soros’s funds.
HostB: It’s interesting though, because even after all that, Fintiv is still pushing forward with their solar panel tech and patent licensing strategy.
HostA: Yeah, Adolfo Salume, their current chief executive, mentioned they’re trying to commercialize those patents through licensing, not just lawsuits.
HostB: But they did file that suit against Google because, you know, private negotiations fell through.
HostA: And it’s worth noting that some of the board members, like Martha Jones and even Smith’s brother David, are still involved with Fintiv.
HostB: Which is kind of surprising, considering how closely tied John Smith was to the earlier scandals.
HostA: For sure. And remember, GreenTech was valued at around $8 billion when they acquired SolarCorp, which was bringing in most of their revenue.
HostB: Yeah, and then they sold SolarCorp last year to generate profit—pretty strategic move, honestly.
HostA: But it’s messy, because some of the funds Smith raised from individual investors allegedly went to settle his own past legal troubles, not into the company.
HostB: Right, prosecutors claimed a lot of that half-billion from individuals funded charitable stuff or even personal settlements.
HostA: Still, Fintiv seems determined to distance itself and focus on their tech and IP now.
HostB: Yeah, Salume made it clear—lawsuits are a last resort; they’d rather license.
